subject: packaging: workaround: x86_64: use 32bits generated sources
commitMessage:
packaging: workaround: x86_64: use 32bits generated sources

Improve previous patch, by avoid to ship 32bits binaries anymore.

Despite it worked for generating images in mic env
it will fail on device.
Since tizen x86_64 does not support 32bits binaries
(even with 32bits libs), it produces errors like :
  cannot execute binary file: Exec format error

Change-Id: I7942f836ed1dc12ce55d56efd9281a5cb63c6b93
Bug-Tizen: TC-1873/related
Signed-off-by: Philippe Coval <philippe.coval@open.eurogiciel.org>

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

It was verified locally using mic and upgrading package
but syslinux can fail in special conditions but this is not related to this change ... anyway there is no obeserved regression on this change

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+1

Indeed there appears to be an issue with gerrit. Yesterday we failed to push a tag to dbus repository. Finally we worked the issue around with the following commands.

 git push -f tizen.org $(cat .git/refs/tags/${THE_TAG}):refs/tags/${THE_TAG}

In case of syslinux I didn't have to hack it this way though.

subject: define _DEFAULT_SOURCE for glibc-2.20
commitMessage:
define _DEFAULT_SOURCE for glibc-2.20

_BSD_SOURCE was deprecated in favour of _DEFAULT_SOURCE since glibc
2.20[1]. To avoid build warning on glibc2.20, _DEFAULT_SOURCE should
also be defined.

[1]: https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/Release/2.20

Change-Id: I13ae76387805fc8844f68dd564a86945bb5fa1cd
Signed-off-by: Chanho Park <chanho61.park@samsung.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think we should post patches dealing with glibc-2.20 changes directly upstream.  I do not think that solution is right, either - if _BSD_SOURCE has no effect it should be simply dropped.

Patch Set 1:

I have checked each file you have modified and I do think we could drop _BSD_SOURCE altogether:

* dos/getsetsl.c - includes inline assembly only with no references to Un*x/posix api

* libinstaller/fs.c - contains references to memcpy/memcmp and few subcalls but none seems to be affected by this define

* libinstaller/syslxmod.c - likewise uses memcmp/set and fprintf but flags shall not have any effect

Thus, I would recommend sending patch (upstream first) that drops _BSD_SOURCE altogether.

Patch Set 1:

Hi Karol,

I sent below patch to syslinux mainline.
http://www.syslinux.org/archives/2014-September/022643.html

But, I can't receive any reply even I send ping request.
I also agree your opinion but I can't ensure whether removing is correct approach. Until they review my patch, I think this is best solution.

Patch Set 1:

It's not clear for me what this change is supposed to achieve.

Maybe this is misunderstanding but commit message says it's supposed to _avoid build warning_.  I do not such warning is problematic _unless_ project wouldn't compile (IOW, it uses -Werror).

I do not think syslinux uses -Werror as there are numerous warnings produced when I try to build it.

Thus, my question is - why do we need to care about this warning at all?

Patch Set 1:

Please see the link in my commit message:
https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/Release/2.20

_BSD_SOURCE was deprecated since glibc-2.20. We have a plan to upgrade glibc to 2.20 version. So, we should add _DEFAULT_SOURCE definition.

In syslinux community, I've got below answer of my patch.
http://www.syslinux.org/archives/2014-September/022653.html

Patch Set 1:

Hi,

I did read glibc 2.20 release document, and I would be very glad if you could be more specific to which part exactly you want me to give more attention to.

I did read "The recommend process for removing the warning is to the following:" but my objection, as stated previously is simple:
 
  "Why do we need care about this warning?"

If this patch fixes build break (-Werror is used) then I understand rationale.  However, that doesn't seem to be the case.

I do not see why we shouldn't just wait for upstream inclusion of your patch (which was different - and better IMHO - than the one here).

Patch Set 1:

Hi Karol,

Please stop this meaningless discussion. Please look other patches which have same issue of this. Most of them could be resolved similarly like me. Syslinux guys also concerned your way. If you're correct, please show me that you're correct. If not, don't catch my words.

Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

I agree that this discussion is not productive and would like to ask others to step up and review it.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I can see several questions that needs to be answered before merging this commit.

1. Does the warning message break anything (-Werror)? If it is just ugly then IMHO our branch is not the right place to fix it and this change should be abandoned.

2. If (and only if) we cannot afford ignoring this warning, then can we remove the _BSD_SOURCE rather than introduce a new define. This is the recommended procedure described on the page referred in the commit message. I had removed the _BSD_SOURCE and built syslinux and there are no warnings related to the missing _BSD_SOURCE define.

Considering the above I oppose this change as it is now as irrelevant to Tizen development.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Hi Lukasz,

Please look previous threads which discussed with Karol.
Actually, I want to review this patch from Intel guy, because Samsung does not use the syslinux package. Finally, this patch was accepted in syslinux community.

http://git.zytor.com/?p=syslinux/syslinux.git;a=commit;h=74b8e263d1c6a787385fed7c2aa70dee4c3795be
Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.
